title: How does it all fit together?
preview: What the conversation jigsaw puzzle looks like so far
body:
This past Thanksgiving, I helped my sister and my nephew put together a 1000-piece jigsaw puzzle. As anyone who has put together a jigsaw puzzle that large knows, it can be quite a challenge to know which pieces fit together with other pieces, and hopefully, no pieces get lost.

Looking back on what I have written over the past year, the topics seem to me like a jigsaw puzzle: many address different aspects of conversations, both face-to-face and online, but the pieces have been jumbled.

I thought it would be good at this point to organize my past thoughts into different themes, with each theme being a piece in a larger puzzle.

To that end, I am creating sections in this article to organize my past articles by theme, with each section containing embedded articles. Some of these embedded articles have other embedded articles within them as well; I recommend you look at those articles, too.

## Table of contents

* [Recognizing a need for change](https://genejoy.substack.com/i/181201380/recognizing-a-need-for-change)

* [Forces at work](https://genejoy.substack.com/i/181201380/forces-at-work)

* [Language and reasoning](https://genejoy.substack.com/i/181201380/language-and-reasoning)

* [Accuracy and charity](https://genejoy.substack.com/i/181201380/accuracy-and-charity)

* [Practice, practice, practice](https://genejoy.substack.com/i/181201380/practice-practice-practice)

* [Missing pieces](https://genejoy.substack.com/i/181201380/missing-pieces)

## Recognizing a need for change

My main reason for starting this publication is that I was dissatisfied with the current state of online conversations. At the same time, I also noticed limitations in face-to-face conversations that online discussions don’t have. We have a lot that is broken in our discourse, and I wanted to name those broken things. The following articles attempt to diagnose the problems I saw.

## Forces at work

There are reasons that our dialogue is broken. For most of us, we mean well, but our aim is off. We need to understand ourselves and others, and take time to think about how we might communicate and respond better. # Language and reasoning

We ought to be mindful of the words we use, what they convey, and how we use them to try to persuade others. Exercising care in our language and reasoning is essential for productive dialogue. ## Accuracy and charity

I emphasize repeatedly the need for accuracy and charity in representing others’ views. This is a basic requirement for good conversations. ## Practice, practice, practice

For many of us who have been online for a while, we often take shortcuts that require less effort but end up making things more difficult in the long run. The habits that make for productive discussions require lots of practice and will be hard at first, but the reward is worth it. The following articles explore good habits that lead to better conversations.

## Missing pieces

I probably am missing some things in the list above; there are likely things I have not covered yet that could shed light on what leads to good conversations. While missing puzzle pieces are a source of anxiety when trying to put together a physical jigsaw puzzle, they are opportunities for writers like me to explore further and think through effective solutions to the problems in our conversations.

And if you happen to find any missing puzzle pieces, please let me know. I’d like to see how they fit in.
